Title: "Multisensory convergence in auditory cortex, I. Cortical connections of the caudal superior temporal plane in macaque monkeys"
Abstract: "The caudal medial auditory area (CM) has anatomical and physiological features consistent with its role as a first-stage (or belt) auditory association cortex. It is also a site of multisensory convergence, with robust somatosensory and auditory responses. In this study, we investigated the cerebral cortical sources of somatosensory and auditory inputs to CM by injecting retrograde tracers in macaque monkeys. A companion paper describes the thalamic connections of CM (Hackett et al., J. Comp. Neurol. [this issue]). The likely cortical sources of somatosensory input to CM were the adjacent retroinsular cortex (area Ri) and granular insula (Ig). In addition, CM had reliable connections with areas Tpt and TPO, which are sites of multisensory integration. CM also had topographic connections with other auditory areas. As expected, connections with adjacent caudal auditory areas were stronger than connections with rostral areas. Surprisingly, the connections with the core were concentrated along its medial side, suggesting that there may be a medial-lateral division of function within the core. Additional injections into caudal lateral auditory area (CL) and Tpt showed similar connections with Ri, Ig, and TPO. In contrast to CM injections, these lateral injections had inputs from parietal area 7a and had a preferential connection with the lateral (gyral) part of Tpt. Taken together, the findings indicate that CM may receive somatosensory input from nearby areas along the fundus of the lateral sulcus. The differential connections of CM compared with adjacent areas provide additional evidence for the functional specialization of the individual auditory belt areas."

@BrainMaps_Delineation.Citation: "Auditory core, belt, and parabelt were identified by using Nissl, AchE, and parvalbumin staining as previously described (Morel et al.,[1993]; Hackett et al.,[1998]). [...] Auditory parabelt areas were considered to be the cortex lateral to belt, including the surface of the superior temporal gryus, sometimes extending past the crest of the superior temporal sulcus, and bordering on areas TAa/TPO described by Seltzer and Pandya ([1978]). [...] Much of the dorsal bank of the STS is occupied by area TPO, which extends along its length and occupies its central part in the medial-lateral axis. This area has been subdivided by different authors (see, e.g., Seltzer and Pandya,[1978],[1989],[1991]; Cusick et al.,[1995]). By using parvalbumin and SMI-32 immunolabeling, we confirmed some features of the subdivisions described by Cusick et al. ([1995]). Following Cusick et al., we placed the rostral border of TPO at approximately the level of the rostral tip of the central sulcus and designated more rostral parts of the dorsal STS as rostral dorsal STS (rdSTS; Table 2). The cortex medial to the caudal portion of TPO in and near the fundus of the STS includes areas MST, MTp, and FST (Seltzer and Pandya,[1978],[1986]; Desimone and Ungerleider,[1986]; Boussaoud et al.,[1990]; Cusick et al.,[1995]) [...] The dorsal part of MT (MTp of Desimone and Ungerleider,[1986]) is less distinctive, [...] On the dorsal surface of the sulcus, the border of Ri with parietal cortex was distinct: parietal cortex was thicker and had less parvalbumin/AchE labeling in layers III/IV (Robinson and Burton,[1980a])."

@InterMapRelations.Citation: "Auditory parabelt areas were considered to be the cortex lateral to belt, including the surface of the superior temporal gryus, sometimes extending past the crest of the superior temporal sulcus, and bordering on areas TAa/TPO described by Seltzer and Pandya ([1978]). Our parabelt corresponds to the caudal part of their area Ts3 as it extends alongside the auditory belt."

"Auditory parabelt areas were considered to be the cortex lateral to belt, including the surface of the superior temporal gryus, sometimes extending past the crest of the superior temporal sulcus, and bordering on areas TAa/TPO described by Seltzer and Pandya ([1978]). Our parabelt corresponds to the caudal part of their area Ts3 as it extends alongside the auditory belt."

"The cortex medial to the caudal portion of TPO in and near the fundus of the STS includes areas MST, MTp, and FST (Seltzer and Pandya,[1978],[1986]; Desimone and Ungerleider,[1986]; Boussaoud et al.,[1990]; Cusick et al.,[1995]). Areas MST occupies the bend of the upper bank of the STS onto the fundus of the STS, situated between caudal TPO and area MT (Boussaoud et al.,[1990]; Cusick et al.,[1995]). The extent of area MT on the ventral bank of the STS was identifiable in our material with parvalbumin and SMI-32 immunolabling (Cusick et al.,[1995]). The dorsal part of MT (MTp of Desimone and Ungerleider,[1986]) is less distinctive, and we did not attempt to distinguish it from area MST. Area FST is situated rostral to MT, and its location was estimated by comparison with previous descriptions. Rostral to FST, the fundus of the STS contains area IPa (Cusick et al.,[1995]) alternatively divided into Ipa and PGa by Seltzer and Pandya ([1978])."

"The cortex medial to the caudal portion of TPO in and near the fundus of the STS includes areas MST, MTp, and FST (Seltzer and Pandya,[1978],[1986]; Desimone and Ungerleider,[1986]; Boussaoud et al.,[1990]; Cusick et al.,[1995]). Areas MST occupies the bend of the upper bank of the STS onto the fundus of the STS, situated between caudal TPO and area MT (Boussaoud et al.,[1990]; Cusick et al.,[1995]). The extent of area MT on the ventral bank of the STS was identifiable in our material with parvalbumin and SMI-32 immunolabling (Cusick et al.,[1995]). The dorsal part of MT (MTp of Desimone and Ungerleider,[1986]) is less distinctive, and we did not attempt to distinguish it from area MST. Area FST is situated rostral to MT, and its location was estimated by comparison with previous descriptions. Rostral to FST, the fundus of the STS contains area IPa (Cusick et al.,[1995]) alternatively divided into Ipa and PGa by Seltzer and Pandya ([1978])."

The dorsal part of MT (MTp of Desimone and Ungerleider,[1986]) is less distinctive, and we did not attempt to distinguish it from area MST. Area FST is situated rostral to MT, and its location was estimated by comparison with previous descriptions. Rostral to FST, the fundus of the STS contains area IPa (Cusick et al.,[1995]) alternatively divided into Ipa and PGa by Seltzer and Pandya ([1978])."

@Methods.Comments: No specification of hemisphere the tracer is injected in

@Injections.Citation: "Injection 1 [Fluoro-ruby (FR) into CM] was made through the cannulated electrode into the caudal-lateral corner of CM, near its borders with CL and Tpt, but appeared be restricted to CM (Fig. 5)."

@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Citation: "Injection 1 [Fluoro-ruby (FR) into CM] was made through the cannulated electrode into the caudal-lateral corner of CM, near its borders with CL and Tpt, but appeared be restricted to CM (Fig. 5). The best frequency (BF) of the site was 1-2 kHz, with sink peak latencies of 13.0 msec for clicks and 15.5 msec for tones. There was no clear somatosensory response to median nerve stimulation in this location. Labeled cells were concentrated in CM, covering most of its area, and also in the adjacent medial belt area MM. Sixty-six percent of the labeled cells in CM were supragranular in origin (Table 2). There were some labeled cells in CL and within the medial side of A1, but otherwise the auditory core and belt areas contained few labeled cells. The caudal parabelt (CPB) contained a narrow zone of labeled cells. Inputs from other areas of the lateral sulcus included projections from the supragranular and infragranular layers of Ri, caudal Ig and Tpt. Labeled cells in the upper bank of the superior temporal sulcus (STS) extended along most of the length of area TPO but were most abundant at about the same anteroposterior coordinate as the injections site in CM (i.e., AP-1.0). Small numbers of cells were found in area IPa in the rostral fundus of the STS. Occasional cells in the parietal cortex might have been caused by slight leakage of tracer along the tract of the injection needle. Thalamic input to this site was mainly from the anterodorsal (MGad) and magnocellular (MGm) divisions of the medial geniculate complex (MGC) and adjoining posterior nucleus (Po; Hackett et al.,[2007a])."

@Injections.Citation: "Injection 3 (FR in CM/Ipa/SII) was in the center of CM (Fig. 7)."

@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Citation: "Injection 3 (FR in CM/Ipa/SII) was in the center of CM (Fig. 7). Dorsally, there was a modest contamination in SII, which was likely to be the source of light supragranular labeling along the length of SII that was not present in other injections of CM. Ventrally, there was a contamination of the fundus of the STS, in cortex identified as Ipa. This contamination is likely to be the source of scattered cells in the rostral extent of the ventral STS (area TEa) and the mainly supragranular labeling along the length of Ipa, extending caudally into areas MT/MST, and in the ventral intraparietal sulcus (area LIP). A similar pattern of labeling was encountered in another injection that also involved the fundus of STS (MAG-CTB; described below). Previous studies also found connections of the fundus of the STS with areas LIP (Cavada and Goldman-Rakic,[1989a]). As in the first two injections, mainly supragranular labeled cells were concentrated in CM and throughout the extent of MM, and a lesser density of cells was found in areas CL, Tpt, and Ri and Ig along the fundus of the sulcus. As in case 1, there was a cluster of mainly infragranular cells in CPB, which might have been obscured by damage to cortex in case 2. In contrast to previous cases, there was substantial concentration of supragranular cells in lateral belt and comparatively more cells in the core auditory cortex (A1).  In the STS, there were labeled cells along the length of TPO. Although their distribution is consistent with the other CM injections, some of this labeling may reflect cells labeled by the tracer deposited in Ipa."

@Injections.Citation: "Injection 2 [Flouro-emerald (FE) into CM/7op] was made into the lateral side of CM, near CL (Fig. 6),"

@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Citation: "There was slight contamination of the dorsal bank of the sulcus into area 7op, but this was small and did not appear to give rise to significant transport. For example, there was no labeling of adjacent areas in the parietal cortex. This monkey had some damage to the lower bank of the lateral sulcus (hatching), which could account for the absence of labeling in the lateral belt and parabelt.The distribution of cells in this injection was similar to that of injection 1. Labeled cells were found throughout CM and MM, and these were 65-72% supragranular. A lower density of cells was found in adjacent areas CL and Tpt, and only scattered cells were seen in areas A1 and Ri and lateral belt (ML). In the STS, there was a cluster of cells in area TPO at about the same rostrocaudal level as the injection and scattered cells scattered rostrally and caudally. A few cells were found in the rostral fundus of the STS."

@Injections.Citation: "Injection 4 [diamidino yellow (DY) in MM/Ri] was centered between Ri medially and A1 laterally (Fig. 8). The injection was at or very near a location shown to have both somatosensory and auditory responses in previous recording sessions. There was a slight deposit of tracer along the electrode tract through Ri in the dorsal bank. However, in contrast to other injections that included Ri (see below), no significant labeling was found in parietal areas outside the lateral sulcus. This injection is described here with other CM injections, because there is at present no compelling reason to consider MM a separate area from CM"

@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Citation: "The pattern of labeling in auditory areas was similar to the other CM injections, with a concentration of cells extending throughout the medial belt (MM and CM). In this more rostral injection, there were comparatively more cells in rostral medial belt (RM) and along the ventral circular sulcus. As in previous injections, areas CL, CPB, and Tpt had significant labeling, but the cells were generally less dense and less supragranular compared with those in areas MM/CM. Labeling in core areas was restricted mainly to the medial half of A1. The Lateral belt (ML) was nearly devoid of labeled cells.  As with injections of CM, areas Ri and Ig were labeled, but in this injection were more dense and extended more rostrally in Ig, and scattered cells were present in SII. In STS, cells were found along the length of TPO, but these were less dense compared with the injections into CM."

@Injections.Citation: "Injection 5 (CTB in CM/A1) was made directly into lateral CM by retracting the upper bank of the lateral fissure but also spread into caudal A1 (Fig. 9)."

@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Citation: "However, in this case, additional scattered cells were found in more rostral insula (Idg), in SII in the dorsal bank of the lateral sulcus, and along almost the entire rostral-caudal extent of the superior bank of the STS. The projection from Tpt was weak in this case, and a few scattered cells were seen in lateral parietal cortex and along the fundus of the STS (area IPa). Consistent with the injection of A1, many labeled cells were found in core areas, especially in caudal A1 near the injection. In R, a patch of labeled cells was located rostrally, possibly corresponding to the high-frequency representation in that area. Beyond the core, labeled cells were found throughout the belt and parabelt regions. Projections from the medial belt were more supragranular caudally (area MM) compared with rostrally (area RM; Table 2). Scattered infragranular cells were also found along the floor of the circular sulcus (CiS) and insula. Connections with the parabelt were and were more abundant in CPB than RPB. Projections from areas outside of auditory core and belt were predominantly from infragranular layers."

@Injections.Citation: "Injection 6 (CTB in CM/Ri) was made directly into cortex at about AP -1.0 after retraction of the upper bank, using electrode penetrations visible on the lower bank as a guide (Fig. 10).The injection was made immediately adjacent to a recording site that had auditory responses to tones and clicks and somatosensory response to median nerve stimulation. The injection appeared to be restricted to CM and the ventral part of Ri."

@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Citation: "Some damage occurred at both the dorsal and the ventral edges of the lateral sulcus (hatching), and this may partially explain the low density of labeling in lateral belt (ML) and parabelt (CPB) areas. In auditory cortex, areas MM and CM contained the most labeled cells, followed by CL (Table 2). A1 had a small number of labeled cells caudally and along its medial border with MM. Outside of auditory cortex, labeling in the lateral sulcus was much more widespread than with CM or CM/A1 injections. Labeling was particularly strong within Ri, as expected, and also included patches of label in SII, Ig, Idg, and within the ventral circular sulcus. n parietal cortex, groups of mixed infragranular and supragranular cells were found in the intraparietal sulcus in areas VIP and AIP and only sparsely on the ventral bank in area LIP. Numerous cells were also clustered on the parietal surface in areas 7b and 7a (Fig. 10). Additional, mainly infragranular cells were found along the dorsal lip of the IPS (area 5v) and on the surface of the postcentral gyrus. These parietal connections appeared to reflect connections of Ri, insofar as these areas were not labeled by CM or CM/A1 injections.  In the STS, connections with TPO were substantial. Additionally, there were scattered cells along the fundus of the STS, both in area Ipa rostrally and also caudally, in cortex tentatively identified as areas FST and MST. The light connections with MST/FST were not found in injections of CM and CM/A1 and might represent connections with Ri."

@Injections.Citation: "The main injection site was in CM, but tracer also spread medially into Ri and also leaked along the injection tract into the surface layers of SII in the upper bank of the lateral sulcus, and ventrally into the fundus of the STS, into cortex tentatively identified as Ipa."

@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Citation: "The pattern of connections substantially overlapped those of injection 6, with some differences. In auditory areas, comparatively more labeled cells were found in belt and parabelt areas (ML, CL, AM, CPB, and RPB; see Table 2). The greater involvement of these auditory areas might have been due to the more rostral placement of the injection in this case. As in previous CM injections, labeling of core auditory cortex was concentrated mainly along the medial edge.  Outside of the auditory cortex, there was substantial labeling in SII and in Ig, presumably because of the involvement of Ri and SII in the injection site. As in injection No. 6, there was a substantial labeling in parietal areas 7a and 7b, AIP, VIP, and 5v and the postcentral gyrus. However, in this case, scattered cells were also found along the anterior and posterior walls of the central sulcus, possibly reflecting the involvement of SII in the injection site. Additionally, as with a previous injection (No. 3) that involved area IPa, labeled cells were distributed along the fundus of STS and along the length of area LIP in the intraparietal sulcus, and these were mainly supragranular."

@Injections.Citation: "Injection 10 (CTB in Tpt) was made after retraction of the upper bank. By cytoarchitectonic criteria, the injection was judged to be at the border of CL and Tpt (Fig. 15). However, the absence of labeled cells in A1 suggests that the injection was mainly in area Tpt."

@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Citation: "Distribution of labeling in this case was similar to that in case 9, although labeling was somewhat less dense in the caudal belt areas (CM, MM, and caudal edge of ML) and in rostral parts of the circular sulcus and insula. As in injection 9, there were clusters of cells in area Ri and the caudal extent of insula area Ig. Laterally, there was dense labeling in caudal parabelt and in gyral Tpt that avoided the caudal-medial sulcus. Labeled cells were dense along area TPO in the dorsal STS, and some labeling was present in the caudal inferior parietal cortex (area 7a)."

@Injections.Citation: "Injection 8 [fast blue (FB) in CM/caudal fundus of lateral sulcus] was made through the cannula into the caudal medial corner of CM (Figs. 12, 13). The injection site in CM exhibited feed-forward response profiles for tones (BF, 500 Hz; 10 msec latency) and median nerve stimulation (11.8 msec) as determined from the sink peak in layer IV. Besides the tracer deposited in CM, there was some leakage into the suclus, causing involvement of superficial layers of its fundus and dorsal bank and spreading mainly caudally from the injection site. Therefore, in addition to CM, the tracer deposit probably included caudal Ri, although its caudal border is poorly defined, and the injection site probably involved to some extent areas 7op and medial Tpt in the caudal lateral sulcus."

@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Citation: "The labeling pattern partially overlapped that of other injections into CM/Ri. As with other CM injections, labeled cells were especially dense near the medial border of A1, and less labeling was seen in lateral belt areas (CL and ML). However, in this case, there was a comparatively high density of cells within A1. In the STS, there were cells in TPO, with a larger cluster at about the same anterior-posterior level as the injections site. As with previous injections that included Ri, there was significant labeling in SII and Ig, VIP, and 7a. However, in this case, the parietal labeling was less robust, probably because of the relatively restricted involvement of Ri compared with previous cases."

@Injections.Citation: "njection 9 (FB in CL/CPB) was made through the cannula into area CL and slightly overlapped with the caudal parabelt (Fig. 14). The upper bank of the sulcus was slightly contaminated by absorption of tracer after contact with the injection site when the retraction was relaxed. However, there did not appear to be significant transport from the upper bank."

@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Citation: "Similar to injections into CM, labeled cells were found in the lateral sulcus in areas Ri, Ig, and circular sulcus. However, in this case, many more cells were found in area Idg in the more rostral insula. Labeled cells also extended caudally into area Tpt, but, in contrast to injections of CM, they were almost completely restricted to its lateral part. Among the auditory areas, there was dense labeling in areas CL and CPB, as expected, and also numerous cells in lateral belt (ML) and in medial belt areas (MM, CM) extending into rostral medial belt (RM). Labeling in A1 was concentrated at its caudal border. There were only a few cells in the rostral core (R) or in rostral lateral belt (AL) or parabelt (RPB).  The caudal areas of the STS upper bank were labeled in both supragranular and infragranular layers, whereas the more rostral areas contained labeled cells in the lower layers only. In contrast to injections involving mainly CM, there was significant labeling of area 7a in the caudal inferior parietal cortex (Fig. 14)."

publication.title: "Multisensory convergence in auditory cortex, I. Cortical connections of the caudal superior temporal plane in macaque monkeys"
publication.abstract: "The caudal medial auditory area (CM) has anatomical and physiological features consistent with its role as a first-stage (or belt) auditory association cortex. It is also a site of multisensory convergence, with robust somatosensory and auditory responses. In this study, we investigated the cerebral cortical sources of somatosensory and auditory inputs to CM by injecting retrograde tracers in macaque monkeys. A companion paper describes the thalamic connections of CM (Hackett et al., J. Comp. Neurol. [this issue]). The likely cortical sources of somatosensory input to CM were the adjacent retroinsular cortex (area Ri) and granular insula (Ig). In addition, CM had reliable connections with areas Tpt and TPO, which are sites of multisensory integration. CM also had topographic connections with other auditory areas. As expected, connections with adjacent caudal auditory areas were stronger than connections with rostral areas. Surprisingly, the connections with the core were concentrated along its medial side, suggesting that there may be a medial-lateral division of function within the core. Additional injections into caudal lateral auditory area (CL) and Tpt showed similar connections with Ri, Ig, and TPO. In contrast to CM injections, these lateral injections had inputs from parietal area 7a and had a preferential connection with the lateral (gyral) part of Tpt. Taken together, the findings indicate that CM may receive somatosensory input from nearby areas along the fundus of the lateral sulcus. The differential connections of CM compared with adjacent areas provide additional evidence for the functional specialization of the individual auditory belt areas."
